results.title: The Stamp Collector
results.brief_description: This compilation program includes two films on stamps in the Australian and Pacific regions. “Pictures that Post” looks at the objects and artworks which have made their way onto our postage stamps. “A Fragile Piece of History” documents the final re-enactment of the tin can mail delivery in the Tongan islands.

results.title: The Staircase
results.brief_description: Academy Award-winning documentary filmmaker, Jean-Xavier de Lestrade, presents a gripping courtroom thriller, offering a rare and revealing inside look at a high-profile murder trial. In 2001, author Michael Peterson was arraigned for the murder of his wife Kathleen, whose body was discovered lying in a pool of blood on the stairway of their home. Granted unusual access to Peterson’s lawyers, home and immediate family, de Lestrade’s cameras capture the defense team as it considers its strategic options. “The staircase” is an engrossing look at contemporary American justice that features more twists than a legal bestseller.

results.title: The Stage to three
results.creator_credit: Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Comparisons”.
An introduction to three entertainers of outstanding talent: Katina Paxinou, an actress from Greece, Chatuporn Ratanavarah, demon dancer of Thailand, and Bruno Gerussi, a Canadian actor.

results.title: The Stable door
results.creator_credit: Pat Jackson, Ronald H. Riley and Ronald H Riley and Associates
results.brief_description: While a gang plan to rob a warehouse, an insurance company tries to persuade the owners of the warehouse to improve their security arrangements. The result proves the value of precautions, which apply equally in the home, office or factory.

results.title: The St Arnaud boys
results.creator_credit: Norm Michael, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Norm started his life in the Army with six other local boys from his local area. He really enjoyed the mateship and sense of community he shared with them, and reminisces on the good times they had over the years. The mateship still lives on today when Norm catches up with them back in their home town, St Arnaud.

results.title: The Squeeze
results.brief_description: An impressionistic study of crowding in the United States as ascertained from statistical information translated into endless rows of sprawling suburban houses, cities devouring the land, the world compressing itself into a sardine can. Voices comment on the appalling implications of an ever swelling world. Indicates the prblems which stem from over-population both in under-developed countries and in the United States.

results.title: The Squatter's Daughter
results.brief_description: In his second feature production, Ken Hall retained little but the title of the old play by Bailey and Duggan which had been more faithfully filmed in 1910. Hall’s film focussed on the rivalry between two sheep stations, one managed by a strong willed woman, Joan Enderby and the other by a weak willed enemy, Clive Sherrington. Hall believed in providing light relief in his dramas and the film introduced some of his most effective comedy sequences. Strong nationalistic sentiment pervades the film, with Frank Hurley’s photography of the outback capturing some vistas of impressive grandeur. Cast includes Jocelyn Howarth, Dick Fair, John Warwick, Fred MacDonald.

Hall’s film focused on the rivalry between two sheep stations; one managed by a strong willed woman, Joan Enderby, and the other by a weak-willed enemy, Clive Sherrington.

Hall believed in providing light relief in his dramas and the film introduced some of his most effective comedy sequences. Strong nationalistic sentiment pervades the film, with Frank Hurley’s photography of the Outback capturing some vistas of impressive grandeur.

Cast includes Jocelyn Howarth, Dick Fair, John Warwick, Fred MacDonald.

results.title: The Squat
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “A Place of Your Own”.
The tape looks at the predicament of the growing number of young people who are homeless. Three people live in a refuge for a time and then decide to occupy, and renovate an abandoned house nearby

results.title: The Square
results.creator_credit: Roast Beef Productions, Worldview Entertainment, Noujaim Films, Jehane Noujaim, Maxyne Franklin and Karim Amer
results.headline_credit: Egypt, United Kingdom and United States of America, 2013
results.brief_description: The Square looks at the hard realities faced day-to-day by people working to build Egypt’s new democracy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Roast Beef Productions, Worldview Entertainment, Noujaim Films, Jehane Noujaim, Maxyne Franklin and Karim Amer
results.headline_credit_for_label: Egypt, United Kingdom and United States of America, 2013
results.description: The Square, a new film by Jehane Noujaim (Control Room; Rafea: Solar Mama), looks at the hard realities faced day-to-day by people working to build Egypt’s new democracy. Catapulting us into the action spread across 2011 and 2012, the film provides a kaleidoscopic, visceral experience of the struggle. Cairo’s Tahrir Square is the heart and soul of the film, which follows several young activists. Armed with values, determination, music, humor, an abundance of social media, and sheer obstinacy, they know that the thorny path to democracy only began with Hosni Mubarek’s fall. The life-and-death struggle between the people and the power of the state is still playing out.

results.title: The Square
results.creator_credit: Elizabeth Mary Moore, Sally Sharpe, Louise Smith, Matthew Dabner, Nash Edgerton, Joel Edgerton, Australian Film Finance Corporation, Blue-Tongue Films, Film Depot Pty. Ltd., New South Wales Film & Television Office and Igloo Films
results.brief_description: Ray, a construction worker trapped in an unhappy marriage, pursues an affair with his neighbor, Carla. Carla’s husband, Greg, is a mobster who keeps large sums of drug money in their home. With this in mind, Carla comes up with a plan: She and Ray will steal Greg’s money, burn down her house, convince Greg the money was lost in the fire and then run away together. Carla’s scheme, however, doesn’t go off as planned.

constellations_other.name: True blue, true crime
constellations_other.description: Robert Connolly's The Dry is a recent Australian crime blockbuster, but the writer, director and producer's first film (and first crime film) connects to a longstanding tradition of true-blue crime stories from some of our greatest filmmakers.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Elizabeth Mary Moore, Sally Sharpe, Louise Smith, Matthew Dabner, Nash Edgerton, Joel Edgerton, Australian Film Finance Corporation, Blue-Tongue Films, Film Depot Pty. Ltd., New South Wales Film & Television Office and Igloo Films
results.description:
Blue-Tongue Films, Australia’s home of neo-noir, cuts their teeth with brothers Nash and Joel Edgerton taking on a domestic disturbance with disastrous consequences.

If there was a force most responsible for the wave of Australian neo-noir kicking off in the naughts, it would be Blue-Tongue Films, the Aussie film collective comprised of – among others – Kieran Darcy-Smith, Luke Doolan, Mirrah Foulkes, David Michôd and Edgerton brothers Nash and Joel. Between their features like Animal Kingdom (2010) and The Magician (2005), and a long catalogue of award-winning shorts, the group’s innate understanding of the rules of the genre mean they’re well-equipped when it comes to subverting them. That’s certainly the case with The Square, directed by Nash, written by Joel, and produced by the pair.

In some aspects a black comedy of errors, it follows Raymond (David Roberts) and Carla (Claire van der Boom) whose ongoing affair has disastrous consequences as seemingly good people make bad decisions. Populated with a who’s who of Aussie day players like Bill Hunter, Anthony Hayes, Damon Herriman and Blue-Tongue boys Darcy-Smith, Doolan and Joel Edgerton filling out the supporting roles, The Square is a nasty lil’ domestic thriller. Earmarking the promise of not just the Edgertons as filmmakers but the collective as a whole, it’s an intricate web of deceit, drama and discomfort that manifests in suburban mayhem.
description_for_label:
